Key Laboratory of Low-grade Energy Utilization Technologies and Systems (Chongqing University) Ministry of Education Chongqing 400030 China Graphical abstract Heterogeneous catalysts with a considerable active surface area are critically important to achieve the excellent catalytic activity. In this work, hence, a hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst with a snow-like Ni nanostructure was prepared by combining the hydrothermal synthesis method with spontaneously galvanic replacement reaction. The snow-like Ni nanostructure on nickel foam not only effectively increased the specific surface area, but also ensured good dispersion of Pd nanocatalyst. Experimental results confirmed that the specific surface area of nickel foam was increased from 1 m2/g to 33 m2/g and the metallic active surface area was promoted from 0.34 m2/g to 1.31 m2/g. The catalytic activity and lifetime of the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst was also evaluated by nitrobenzene hydrogenation. It was demonstrated that, benefited from the higher catalytic surface area and the strong interaction between Pd and NiO, the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst could present both higher catalytic performance (TOF = 242 h−1) and lifetime than the conventional catalyst. Keywords Snow-like Ni nanostructure Hierarchical catalyst Nitrobenzene hydrogenation Catalytic performance 1 Introduction The heterogeneous catalytic synthesis of aniline has attracted wide attention due to broad application prospects and market demand [1]. To date, various methods [2–5] have been reported. Among them, the aniline synthesis by the nitrobenzene hydrogenation holds dominant position owing to the mild reaction conditions and high-quality product. However, limited by serious mass transfer between the phases in the reactors, high operating pressure and/or temperature and intensive mixing are usually necessary [6,7]. Under this circumstance, mass transfer enhancement by microreactors has been proposed and become a hot research topic [8,9]. Some microreactors, such as the microchannel reactor [10], falling film microreactor [11] and catalytic membrane microreactor [12] have been developed. These microreactors can effectively intensify the mass transfer and improve the performance, whereas further improvement of the microreactor performance is still restricted by small surface area for loading the nanocatalyst. As a result, the microreactors with three-dimensional structures were designed by employing the porous materials, such as zeolite, fibers, metal foam [13–15], etc. Among these porous materials, metal foam has been widely used for the exploitation of the microreactors due to its properties of high accessible porosity, low pressure drop and commercially availability. Recently, some studies have been put forward to the catalyst deposition on the metal foam. For example, Li et al. [16] developed the Ni-Al2O3 catalysts on metal foam by a modified wet chemical etching method. Lali et al. [17] deposited the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst on aluminum foam by the impregnation-reduction method. Although promising, the catalyst dispersion still faces the roadblocks arising from limited surface area of the metal foam. To address this issue, hierarchical porous structure with bi- and/or even tri-modal pore structure are proposed. The incorporation of macropores with micropores and/or mesopores can not only provide larger surface area for loading the catalyst deposition, but also potentially enhance the transport of reagents in such a hierarchical structure [18]. For this reason, a series of hierarchical catalysts has been developed based on the metal foam, such as the hierarchical NiCo2S4 nanowire arrays prepared by the hydrothermal method [19], the hierarchical NiO array prepared through “Twin metalsource” method [20], the hierarchical CuO–CeO2/Ni foam prepared through spin coating combined with the doctor blading method, the hierarchical mesoporous transition metal oxides arrays obtained from chemical bath deposition (CBD) followed by calcination [21], etc. To our knowledge, the hierarchical catalysts toward the nitrobenzene hydrogenation have not yet been reported. It is well known that catalysts, such as Pd, Pt or PdNi alloy [4,7,22–24], have been widely used in the hydrogenation of nitroaromatic compounds due to their high activity and selectivity. Loading these catalysts in the hierarchical porous structure can be a promising method to improve the performance of nitrobenzene hydrogenation. However, the common methods [25–27], like impregnation-reduction, thermal decomposition, electroless deposition, etc., usually require a complex manufacturing process, which may not only increase the manufacturing cost but also deteriorate the hierarchical structure. Therefore, a facile method for preparing the catalysts by galvanic replacement reaction was put forward [22,28], by which the metal catalyst could be easily deposited on the metal substrate owing to the large potential difference between the metals. In this case, the preparation process can be simplified and the structure of the metal substrate can be maintained. Inspired by the hierarchical porous structure along with the merits of the galvanic replacement reaction, a hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst with a snow-like Ni nanostructure on Ni foam was proposed to realize the nitrobenzene hydrogenation in this work. Here, the uniform snow-like Ni nanostructure on Ni foam was firstly formed through hydrothermal method, on which the Pd nanocatalyst was then prepared by the spontaneously galvanic replacement reaction. The catalytic activity and lifetime toward nitrobenzene hydrogenation under various operation conditions were explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this work, commercial Ni foam (Kunshan Jiayisheng Electronic CO.) with the pore density of 110 ppi, bulk density of 0.2 g/cm3, surface area of 1 m2/g and pore size of 250 μm was used as the porous substrate for the snow-like Ni nanostructure synthesis and the subsequent Pd nanocatalyst deposition. Fig. 1 a schematically describes the preparation process of the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst, which included the hydrothermal synthesis of the snow-like Ni nanostructure and the subsequent deposition of Pd catalyst by galvanic replacement. The formation process of the snow-like Ni nanostructure is illustrated in Fig. 1b. First of all, the Ni foam was ultrasonically cleaned in acetone, 0.2 mol/L hydrochloric acid and ethanol, successively. Second, 100 mL solution containing 1.5 g NiCl2·6H2O, 40.0 g NaOH and 3.0 g cetyl-trimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) was prepared and followed by adding 5 mL N2H4·H2O (85%) in the above prepared solution with additional 15-min stirring. At last, the solution and Ni foam were put into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave for the hydrothermal reaction. Afterwards, the autoclave was naturally cooled down to room temperature. The original gray Ni foam became a black solid product, indicating the formation of the snow-like Ni nanostructure on the surface of Ni foam. Then the product (hierarchical Ni) was obtained by washing with deionized water and pure ethanol for several times to remove any remaining impurities and dried in a vacuum freeze-drying equipment for 6 h. For the Pd deposition by the galvanic replacement reaction, the as-synthesized hierarchical Ni was put into 5 mM H2PdCl4 aqueous solution, and the amount of the final Pd catalyst was dependent on the quantity of H2PdCl4 in the aqueous solution. After the galvanic replacement reaction between PdCl4 2− and Ni, the product termed as hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst was washed with deionized water and dried by a vacuum freeze-drying equipment for 6 h. In this process, the transformation of Pd2+ to Pd0 and Ni0 to Ni2+ could be expressed as PdCl4 2−+Ni→Pd + Ni2++4Cl-. For comparison, a monolithic catalyst was also prepared through direct galvanic replacement reaction between the Pd ions and the raw Ni foam, termed as Pd@Ni catalyst. Besides, a Pd/PDA/Ni foam monolithic catalyst prepared by our previous method [15] was also achieved for comparison. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface morphology of the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst was characterized by a scanning electron microscope (Mira3 LMH, Czech Republic). The surface area was measured by standard Brunauer–Emmett–Teller(BET)method using a physical adsorption instrument (ASAP 2460, Micromeritics, US). The elemental compositions of the catalysts were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (D8 Advance, Bruker, Germany). Temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) was employed for evaluating the interaction between the metal and support. In each H2-TPR experiment, the 100-mg sample was pretreated by N2 at 150 °C for 1 h and then heated from 20 °C to 500 °C in a gas mixture of 10% H2 and N2 with the flow rate of 50 mL min−1 at a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1. CO pulse adsorption (ASAP 2020, Micromeritics, US) was employed to estimate the number of surface Pd sites per unit mass of catalyst on the basis of the adsorption stoichiometry of 1/1 CO/Pd at 20 °C. After degassing under helium condition at 300 °C for 1 h, the sample was reduced at 150 °C for 1 h using a 10% (v/v) mixture of H2/N2. The CO adsorption on the Ni foam was ignorable [28]. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation To evaluate the catalytic performance of the prepared hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst for the nitrobenzene hydrogenation, a reaction chamber (80.0 mm in length, 4.0 mm in width, and 1.5 mm in height) was chosen to assemble the microreactor. The liquid reactant and hydrogen were simultaneously introduced into the reactor by using a syringe pump (Longer, China) and a mass flow controller (Omega, USA), respectively. The reaction was operated under the continuous flow mode at ambient temperature and pressure (25 °C, 0.1 MPa). The inlet nitrobenzene concentration was set at 50 mM by dissolving it in a mixture of anhydrous ethanol and deionized water with a volume ratio of 7:3. The inlet liquid reactant was maintained at a LHSV = 3.1 h−1 corresponding to the liquid flow rate of 1.5 mL·h−1 and the hydrogen flow rate was 9 mL·h−1. Here, LHSV is defined as the handling volume of liquid reactant per reaction volume and hour. The product was collected at the outlet by a collector every hour and the aniline concentration was analyzed by gas chromatograph (Agilent, USA) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The hierarchical structured Ni foam Previous works have demonstrated that both the reaction temperature and reaction time as well as the addition of structure-directing agent can play important roles in the Ni nanostructure [29,30]. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of six different nanostructures prepared under different conditions. All the peak positions were consistent without extra peaks. The characteristic peaks at 44.60°, 51.94° and 76.49° could be indexed to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of Ni (JCPDS Card No. 04-0850), respectively. All the peaks were assigned to the pure phase of fcc Ni. The above results indicated that the prepared six different Ni nanostructures had the same crystal plane, which grew up in accordance with the epitaxial growth mechanism. Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of the raw Ni foam, the hierarchical Ni foams prepared without and with the structure-directing agent of CTAB under the reaction temperature of 160 °C and reaction time of 8 h. As shown in Fig. 3a and b, the raw Ni foam showed a smooth surface and the hierarchical Ni prepared without CTAB showed sphere Ni nanostructure. However, when the CTAB was added, distinct uniform three-dimensional structures with omnidirectional protrusions (snow-like nanostructure) could be observed in Fig. 3c. This result indicated that the structure-directing agent was necessary for the formation of the snow-like nanostructure. Fig. 4 shows the effect of hydrothermal temperature on the formation of the Ni nanostructure. The hydrothermal temperature ranged from 120 °C to 200 °C, and the hydrothermal time was kept at 8 h. As shown, when the temperature was 120 °C (see Fig. 4a), the Ni nanostructure on the Ni foam consisted of agglomerated nanorods with a small number of protrusions. When the temperature was increased to 160 °C, the snow-like nanostructure was prolonged, and uniform three-dimensional structures with the protrusions in many directions were formed (see Fig. 3b). With the further increase of the temperature, the diameter of the Ni nanorods was increased (see Fig. 4b). These phenomena could be attributed to the fact that low temperature was not favorable for the growth of the Ni nanostructure. With the increased temperature, the Ni (111) plane with high surface energy had favorable growth due to the surface energy of each crystal surface in fcc structure, which was elucidated in a sequence of (111) > (100) > (110). At higher temperature, the transformation of Ni nanostructure could be attributed to the increased growth rate of another plane apart from Ni (111). Fig. 5 illustrates the effect of the hydrothermal time on the Ni nanostructure under the reaction temperature of 160 °C. Similarly, for a hydrothermal time of 4 h (see Fig. 5a), the Ni nanostructure mainly consisted of small nanorods in the form of large clusters. Whereas the thicker nanorods and larger clusters were formed with the increase of the hydrothermal time (see Fig. 5b). This is because long reaction time contributed to the occurrence of Ostwald ripening process and thus led to the formation of thicker nanorods and larger clusters. Furthermore, to verify the morphology of the presented nanostructure, the TEM characterizations were also performed and the results are shown in Fig. S1-S3. It was found that the TEM results well agreed with the SEM results under the same prepared conditions. It is further confirmed the reaction temperature and reaction time as well as the addition of structure-directing agent show significant effect on the formed nanostructure. In addition, the specific surface areas of the Ni nanostructures formed under different conditions were also compared and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . Clearly, the formed Ni nanostructure obviously improved the specific surface area as compared to the raw Ni foam. The Ni foam with the snow-like Ni nanostructure showed a maximum specific surface area of about 33 m2/g. The results were consistent with the morphologies of the Ni nanostructures. It can be foreseen that such a snow-like nanostructure with high specific surface area is able to provide larger surface area for the deposition and to enhance the dispersion of the palladium catalyst. 3.2 The palladium catalysts After analyzing the Ni nanostructure on Ni foam, hierarchical Pd@Ni catalysts with different Pd loadings were characterized. The theoretical and actual loadings of Pd are shown in Table 1 . Here, the theoretical and actual loadings were obtained according to the amount of added precursor and ICP-OES analysis, respectively. As shown in Table 1, the actual contents of Pd in the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalysts were less than the Pd@Ni catalysts. This may be due to the fact that the Ni nanostructure with high surface energy tended to form NiO in galvanic replacement reaction, which may be adverse to the replacement of Pd. To further reveal the `properties of the prepared catalyst, a Pd@Ni and a hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst with theoretical loadings of 2 wt.% were used as probes. According to the CO chemical adsorption characterization, the metallic active surface area based on Pd metal for the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst was estimated to be 1.31 m2/g, which was much larger than the Pd@Ni catalyst of 0.34 m2/g. This result confirmed that the Ni nanostructure with high specific surface area could improve the dispersion of palladium. In addition, XRD and H2-TPR characterizations were performed to obtain the crystal structure and interaction between the Ni and Pd species, respectively. Fig. 7 a shows the XRD patterns of Pd@Ni, hierarchical Ni and hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst. It is seen that when palladium catalyst was loaded directly on the untreated nickel foam, two additional peaks were observed at 2θ = 40.12° and 46.52°. By comparing this pattern with the standard pattern (JCPDS Card No. 46-1063), it could be known that Pd metal was successfully deposited on the Ni foam. The grain size of palladium catalyst could be estimated to be about 21.4 nm based on Scherrer equation, which was consistent with the TEM results (19.0 nm) shown in Fig. 7b. When the palladium catalyst was deposited on the hierarchical Ni foam, there was no peak for palladium and an additional peak at 38.37° was observed. This characteristic peak was attributed to the interaction between NiO and Pd metal [22] due to the diffraction peaks of NiO (101) and Pd (111) at 37.25° (JCPDS Card No. 44-1159) and 40.12° (JCPDS Card No. 46-1043), respectively. NiO was mainly produced from the galvanic replacement reaction between Pd2+ and Ni metal. The size of palladium nanoparticle was about 15 nm determined by the TEM characterization (Fig. 7c). Fig. 7d shows the H2-TPR profiles of the Pd@Ni and hierarchical Pd@Ni catalysts. In the Pd@Ni catalyst, one main reduction peak was detected at 302 °C as a result of the reduction of bulk NiO [4]. However, for the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst, a reduction peak was detected at 201 °C with a shoulder peak at 225 °C. The shift in the reduction peak to a lower temperature relative to the Pd@Ni was attributed to the highly dispersed Ni species. The peak at the low temperature (˜201 °C) could be related to the reduction of the NiO species having strong interactions with Pd, while the weak peak at higher temperature (˜225 °C) could be related to the reduction of the NiO species having weak interactions with Pd [28]. In summary, the above results confirmed strong interaction between Pd and NiO, which was consistent with the XRD results. 3.3 Performance evaluation In this section, the nitrobenzene hydrogenation was used as a reference reaction to investigate the catalytic activity. The results are shown in Fig. 8 . It can be seen that the catalytic activity of the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalysts (except the one prepared under conditions of 160 °C and 8 h in the presence of CTAB) decreased gradually during 10-h operation. The catalytic activity and lifetime of the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst prepared at 160 °C for 8 h in the presence of CTAB were significantly improved. After the 30-h operation, the conversion of nitrobenzene was still above 93%. Such dramatic improvement in both the catalytic activity and lifetime could be attributed to the difference in the Ni nanostructure, which significantly affect the specific surface area and the subsequent catalyst deposition. To further demonstrate the superiority of the proposed catalyst, the performances of the Ni foam, hierarchical Ni, Pd@Ni, Pd/PDA/Ni foam (prepared by our previous method) and hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst under the same operating conditions were compared. As shown in Fig. 9 , they displayed dramatically different results. The performance of the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst was better than non-hierarchical catalysts. The improved performance could be attributed to higher surface area provided by the snow-like Ni nanostructure, which improved the loading area and enhanced the dispersion of the Pd catalyst. Moreover, a strong interaction between Pd and NiO existed in the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst. This strong interaction could increase the binding force between catalyst and support, and thus may limit the aggregation and shedding of Pd catalyst in reaction process [5]. In this case, better catalytic activity and lifetime was guaranteed. In addition, the hydrogenation activity of hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst has also been compared with various reported catalysts applicable to hydrogenation of nitroaromatic compounds in terms of TOF values in Table 2 . Here, the TOF is defined as the number of moles of reactant converted by per mole active components per hour. As shown, the conversion of nitrobenzene by the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst reached 93% and the TOF was 242 h−1 within 30 h operation at ambient temperature and pressure. The superior catalytic performance under the mild reaction conditions further demonstrated that the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst possessed promising application potential. 3.4 Effect of the catalyst loading The effects of the Pd loading on the catalytic performance of nitrobenzene hydrogenation are presented in this section. One should note that as compared to the theoretical Pd loadings of 1 wt.%, 2 wt.% and 4 wt.%, the actual Pd loadings were always smaller, as shown in Table 1. The detailed values were 0.70 wt.%, 0.84 wt.%, 2.02 wt.% for the Pd@Ni catalysts, and 0.51 wt.%, 0.73 wt.%, 1.50 wt.% for hierarchical Pd@Ni catalysts, respectively. According to the actual Pd loadings, the abovementioned catalysts were termed as 0.7Pd@Ni, 0.8Pd@Ni, 2.0Pd@Ni and h0.5Pd@Ni, h0.7Pd@Ni, h1.5Pd@Ni. Fig. 10 a and b shows the nitrobenzene conversions by the Pd@Ni and hierarchical Pd@Ni catalysts, respectively. As shown in Fig. 10a, the nitrobenzene conversion by the Pd@Ni catalyst gradually declined. When the 2.0Pd@Ni catalyst was used, the conversion could reach a maximum value of 85.5%, which was higher than the 0.8Pd@Ni catalyst. However, the conversion of the 2.0Pd@Ni catalyst was unable to remain stable during 10-hour operation, which showed quick reduction as compared to the 0.8Pd@Ni catalyst. But both of them showed better performance than the 0.7Pd@Ni catalyst. This phenomenon may be attributed to the following reasons. First, 0.7Pd@Ni had too low Pd loading to facilitate complete reaction of the reactants and more intermediate products (nitrosobenzene) were then generated, which covered the active sites of the catalyst and thus led to a very low conversion. The conversion and lifetime could be improved by increasing the catalyst loading to 0.84 wt.%, (the 0.8Pd@Ni catalyst). However, when the Pd catalyst loading was further increased, no more surface area was available for loading the Pd catalyst since the surface area of the Ni foam was small and fixed. Hence, catalyst agglomeration likely occurred, causing the active surface area of the catalyst to decrease. Fig. 11 a shows the SEM images of the 2.0Pd@Ni catalyst, which displayed a Pd film consisting of aggregated Pd nanoparticles. After the nitrobenzene hydrogenation reaction, the catalyst was peeled off from the Ni foam (see Fig. 11b), which may lead to rapid decrease in the nitrobenzene conversion. As a result, although the 2.0Pd@Ni catalyst could show better performance as a result of high catalyst loading, quick reduction was observed. For the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst, the nitrobenzene conversion was clearly better than that by the Pd@Ni catalyst, as shown in Fig. 10b. However, the h0.5Pd@Ni catalyst showed almost the same decline trend with the 0.7Pd@Ni catalyst. This is because the high concentration of inlet nitrobenzene and the low loading of catalyst led to the over load to the reactor, which resulted in quick catalyst inactivation. Second, the actual content of Pd for the h0.5Pd@Ni catalyst was smaller than that for the 0.7Pd@Ni catalyst (Table 1). Therefore, the performance of the h0.5Pd@Ni catalyst was poorer than that of the 0.7Pd@Ni catalyst. However, with the increase of the catalyst loading, this phenomenon could be effectively alleviated and the nitrobenzene conversion remained 93% for 30 h. Furthermore, owing to the high specific surface area of hierarchical porous structure, the nitrobenzene conversion was further improved to 95% when the h1.5Pd@Ni catalyst was used. Moreover, no agglomeration or exfoliation (see Fig. 11c and d) occurred for the h1.5Pd@Ni catalyst due to the strong interaction between Pd and NiO, which facilitated a higher and more stable conversion. Finally, the carbon balance for the Pd@Ni catalyst and hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst were also calculated because it could reflect the equilibrium of the reactant before and after reaction and was a standard to verify the reliability of data. The results are listed in Table S1. It was shown that the values of carbon balance were more than 99%, meaning that the data presented in this work was reliable. Meanwhile, the maximum uncertainly in the measurement was 5.7%. 4 Conclusions In this work, the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst with a snow-like nanostructure on nickel foam was developed by a facile and efficient method, which consisted of the hydrothermal synthesis of the snow-like Ni nanostructure on the nickel foam and subsequent galvanic replacement deposition of Pd nanocatalyst. Effects of the preparation conditions on the snow-like nanostructure were discussed. Meanwhile, the catalytic activity and lifetime toward nitrobenzene hydrogenation under various preparation conditions were explored. Experimental results demonstrated that the nanostructure formed under different hydrothermal conditions all belonged to Ni species but the snow-like Ni nanostructure showed the higher specific surface area. It was also found that, when Pd nanocatalyst was deposited through galvanic replacement reaction, a high dispersion of palladium and a strong interaction between Pd and NiO were obtained, which guaranteed the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst to possess better catalytic activity and lifetime for nitrobenzene hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous catalysts with a considerable active surface area are critically important to achieve the excellent catalytic activity. In this work, hence, a hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst with a snow-like Ni nanostructure was prepared by combining the hydrothermal synthesis method with spontaneously galvanic replacement reaction. The snow-like Ni nanostructure on nickel foam not only effectively increased the specific surface area, but also ensured good dispersion of Pd nanocatalyst. Experimental results confirmed that the specific surface area of nickel foam was increased from 1 m2/g to 33 m2/g and the metallic active surface area was promoted from 0.34 m2/g to 1.31 m2/g. The catalytic activity and lifetime of the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst was also evaluated by nitrobenzene hydrogenation. It was demonstrated that, benefited from the higher catalytic surface area and the strong interaction between Pd and NiO, the hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst could present both higher catalytic performance (TOF = 242 h−1) and lifetime than the conventional catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Hierarchical Pd@Ni catalyst with a snow-like nanostructure on Ni foam for nitrobenzene hydrogenation
